preparation: Mix all ingredients in an old fashioned glass over ice; stir.
name: Vieux Carré
El Comendador
preparation: Combine ingredients in shaker tin. Muddle kiwi until crushed. Add a few pebbles of crushed ice and whip to froth pineapple juice. Dump into collins glass 1/2 filled with crushed ice. Top with crushed ice.

name: Apertif
preparation: Mix all ingredients and carbonate. Pour over ice. Alternatively, shake and strain.

name: Brandy Crusta
preparation: Prepare glass by moistening the rim with lemon and dipping it in sugar, then carefully curling the lemon peel around the inside of the glass. Combine all ingredients in a shaker, shake and strain into glass and add 1 small cube of ice.
Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Bacardi

preparation: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.  Add three dashes of syrup.
name: Rose
Old Fashioned
preparation: Place sugar cube in old fashioned glass and saturate with bitters, add a dash of plain water. Muddle until dissolve. Fill the glass with ice cubes and add whisky.

name: Tuxedo
preparation: Stir all ingredients with ice and strain into glass.

name: Mojito
preparation: Muddle mint springs with sugar and lime juice. Add splash of soda water and fill glass with cracked ice. Pour rum and top with soda water. Serve with straw.

name: Horse's Neck
preparation: Build into highball glass with ice cubes. Stir gently. If required, add dashes of Angostura bitters.

name: Sea Breeze
preparation: Build all ingredients in a glass filled with ice.
Shake and strain into a chilled flute. Dash some Angostura bitters on top.
name: Pisco Sour
Long Island Iced Tea
preparation: Add all ingredients into highball glass filled with ice. Stir gently. Serve with straw.
Shake with ice cubes. Strain into glass.
name: Angel Face
Mimosa
preparation: Pour orange juice into flute and gently pour Champagne. Stir gently. Note: a Buck’s Fizz and a Mimosa are the same drink.

name: Whiskey Sour
preparation: Dash egg white (Optional: if used shake little harder to foam up the egg white). Pour all ingredients into cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake. Strain into cocktail glass. If served ‘On the rocks’, strain ingredients into old fashioned glass filled with ice.
garnish: Half an orange slice and cherry

name: Screwdriver
preparation: Build into a highball glass filled with ice. Stir gently.

name: Cuba Libre
preparation: Build all ingredients in a highball glass filled with ice.
Shake with ice cubes. Strain into cocktail glass. Sprinkle with fresh ground nutmeg.
name: Porto Flip
Gin Fizz
preparation: Shake all ingredients with ice cubes, except soda water. Pour into glass. Top with soda water.
Shake and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Espresso Martini

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into cocktail glass rimmed with salt (note: Fruit Margarita - blend selected fruit with the above recipe).
name: Margarita

preparation: Shake and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Yellow Bird
Pina Colada
preparation: Blend all the ingredients with ice in a electric blender, pour into a large goblet or Hurricane glass and serve with straws.
Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
name: Aviation

preparation: Pour peach puree into chilled glass and add sparkling wine. Stir gently. Variations: Puccini (fresh mandarin juice), Rossini (fresh strawberry puree), Tintoretto (fresh pomegranate juice)
name: Bellini

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Grasshopper
Tequila Sunrise
preparation: Build tequila and orange juice into highball with ice cubes. Add a splash of grenadine to create sunrise effect. Do not stir.
Shake and strain.
name: Daiquiri

preparation: Layer ingredients one at a time starting with Kahlúa, followed by Baileys Irish Cream and top with Grand Marnier. Flame the Grand Marnier, serve while the flame is still on, accompanied with a straw on side plate.
name: B52
Rusty Nail
preparation: Build into old fashioned glass filled with ice. Stir gently.
Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain.
name: Stinger

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Golden Dream
Spritz Veneziano
preparation: Build into an old fashioned glass filled with ice. Top with a splash of soda water.
Build into old fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently.
name: God Mother
Bramble
preparation: Build over crushed ice. Stir, then pour the blackberry liqueur over the top of the drink in a circular fashion.
Shake and strain into a chilled glass. Sprinkle with fresh ground nutmeg.
name: Alexander
Lemon Drop Martini
preparation: Shake and strain into a chilled glass rimmed with sugar.
Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass. Squeeze oil from lemon peel onto the drink.
name: French Martini

preparation: Build into old fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently. Note: for White Russian, float fresh cream on the top and stir gently.
name: Black Russian
Bloody Mary
preparation: Stir gently, pour all ingredients into glass.

name: Mai-tai
preparation: Shake and strain into glass. Serve with straw.
garnish: Pineapple spear, mint leaves and lime wedge

preparation: Pour all ingredients in a chilled glass.  Top with Prosecco.
name: Barracuda
Sex on the Beach
preparation: Build all ingredients in a glass filled with ice.
Shake and strain into chilled glass.
name: Monkey Gland
Derby
preparation: Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into glass.
Shake with ice cubes. Strain into glass.
name: Sidecar

preparation: Warm the Irish whiskey over a burner. Pour into the glass (for hot drink) hot coffee, and add a teaspoon of sugar. Float Cream on top.
name: Irish Coffee
Americano
preparation: Build into glass filled with ice cubes. Add a splash of soda water.

name: Singapore Sling
preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into glass.
Build into glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently.
name: French Connection
Moscow Mule
preparation: Combine the vodka and ginger beer. Add lime juice.

name: John Collins
preparation: Build into glass filled with ice. Stir gently. Add a dash of Angostura bitters. (Note: Use Old Tom Gin for Tom Collins)
Pour Créme de Cassis into glass, top up with white wine. For Kir Royal: Use champagne instead of white wine.
name: Kir
Mint Julep
preparation: In the glass, gently muddle the mint, sugar and water. Fill the glass with cracked ice, add Bourbon and stir well until the glass is frost.
Shake and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Tommy's Margarita

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Paradise
Dirty Martini
preparation: Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.

name: Champagne Cocktail
preparation: Add dash of Angostura bitter onto sugar cube and drop it into champagne flute. Add cognac followed by pouring gently chilled champagne.
Shake and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Mary Pickford

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into a double cocktail glass.
name: Hemingway Special
Dark 'n' Stormy
preparation: Build into glass filled with ice. Add rum first and top it with ginger beer.
Pour all ingredients (except soda) in a mixing glass, dry shake (no ice) for two minutes, add ice and hard shake for another minute. Strain into glass without ice, top with soda.
name: Ramos Fizz
Russian Spring Punch
preparation: Shake the ingredients and pour into glass. Top with Sparkling wine.
Build into glass filled with ice cubes. Stir gently.
name: God Father
Cosmopolitan
preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into a large cocktail glass.
Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass. Squeeze oil from lemon peel onto the drink, or garnish with olive.
name: Dry Martini

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Between the Sheets
Casino
preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
Place lime and sugar in glass and muddle. Fill glass with ice and Cachaca (note: for a Caipiroska, use Vodka instead of Cachaca).
name: Caipirinha
Vampiro
preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into glass, filled with ice.
garnish: Lime wedge and a green or red chili

preparation: Shake and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Kamikaze

preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into large glass.
name: White Lady
Harvey Wallbanger
preparation: Build vodka and orange juice into a highball glass filled with ice. Stir gently and float Galliano on top.
Pour all ingredients into a cocktail shaker.  Shake and strain into a glass filled with ice.
name: Mudslide

preparation: Pour the coffee liqueur and cream into a cocktail shaker filled with ice.  Shake well and strain into a highball filled with ice.  Top with club soda.
name: Smith & Kearns

preparation: Pour the ingredients into a mixing glass with ice cubes.  Stir well and strain into a chilled glass.
name: Orange Blossom
Hollywood
preparation: Pour the liquors into a glass filled with ice.  Fill with pineapple juice.

name: Fuzzy Navel
preparation: Pour the peach schnapps into a glass filled with ice cubes.  Top with orange juice.  Stir well.

name: Freddie Fuddpucker
preparation: Build tequila and orange juice into a glass filled with ice. Stir gently and float Galliano on top.

name: Bocce Ball
preparation: Pour the vodka, amaretto, and orange juice into a glass filled with ice. Add a splash of soda water.

name: Bay Breeze
preparation: Pour the vodka into a ice filled glass.  Fill with equal parts of both juices.
Pour the liquors into a glass filled with ice.  Fill with orange juice.
name: Alabama Slammer
Pamplemousse
preparation: Pour all ingredients into rinsed shaker, shake on ice and double strain into glass.
Dry shake, then shake on ice, and fine strain.
name: Brass Rail
City Honey Bee
preparation: Pour all ingredients into a shaker, shake, and strain into glass.

name: Trident
preparation: Stir all ingredients with ice. Strain into glass.
Stir well with cracked ice, then strain into a chilled glass.
name: Suburban
Floradora
preparation: Pour the gin, lime juice, and framboise into a highball glass filled with ice. Top with ginger ale.
Stir all ingredients with ice. Strain into glass.
name: Ampersand
Ti' Punch
preparation: Add both ingredients and stir.  Can be served up or down, and with or without ice.

name: Shopping List
preparation: Add both ingredients and stir.  Can be served up or down, and with or without ice.

name: Bartender's Choice
preparation: Add both ingredients and stir.  Can be served up or down, and with or without ice.

name: Pimm's Cup
preparation: Pour the Pimm's into a collins glass with ice cubes.  Add the lemonade and (if desired) a splash of club soda or lemon-lime soda.
Stir on ice, serve on the rocks.
name: Japanese
description: Described by the *Minneapolis Tribune* in 1886 as 'liquid attack of spinal meningitis. It is loaded with knock-kneed mental ceramics, and is apt to make a man throw stones at his grandfather'.

preparation: Shake well with ice and strain into a cocktail glass.
name: De Rigueur
description: From [The Savoy Cocktail Book](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1862057729?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1862057729&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20).

preparation: Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Rob Roy
description: If you think this sounds like a Manhattan except with scotch -- that's because it is.  (Except usually sweeter.).

preparation: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice. Stir gently and strain into a rocks glass with a large ice cube.
name: Penicillin
description: *There is a special rung in Hell reserved for people who waste good Scotch.* ~ Inglorious Basterds

name: Mark Twain
preparation: Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice, add ice and shake vigorously, strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Royal Smile
preparation: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously.
description: Autumn in a cocktail glass.

preparation: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously.
name: Jake Barnes

preparation: Shake all the ingredients with ice.
name: Black Martini #1

preparation: Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Bobby Burns
description: The Bobby Burns cocktail is named after the Scottish poet Robert Burns, who is known as the national poet of Scotland and beat out William Wallace for the title of “The Greatest Scot” on Scottish TV. (He wrote *Auld Lang Syne*!)

preparation: Rinse a chilled old fashioned glass with the absinthe, add crushed ice and set it aside. Stir the remaining ingredients over ice and set it aside. Discard the ice and any excess absinthe from the prepared glass, and strain the drink into the glass. Note: The original recipe changed after the American Civil War, rye whiskey substituted cognac as it became hard to obtain.
name: Sazerac
description: This concoction gained popularity and was eventually served at the Merchants Exchange Coffee House (perhaps akin to the 'coffee shops' of Amsterdam?) which specifically used Sazerac-de-Forge et Fils Cognac as its base spirit. In 1859, John Schiller acquired the Merchants Exchange Coffee House, renaming it to the Sazerac Coffee House and between the use of Sazerac Cognac and being served at the Sazerac Coffee House that this cocktail received its name. According to Stanley Clisby Arthur, author of the 1937 [Famous New Orleans Drinks and How to Mix ''Em](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0882891324?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=0882891324&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20), at some point in the following decade, Leon Lamothe, a bartender at the Sazerac Coffee House, thought to add a dash of absinthe. Unfortunately, starting in the in the 1860s, Europe's vineyards were decimated by the phylloxera plague, which severely curtailed the availability of Cognac for the original Sazerac. It was around this time that the Sazerac that we know today finally took shape, as a Thomas (John?) H. Handy, a new owner of the Sazerac Coffee House, changed the base spirit from cognac to rye whiskey.

preparation: Combine in a cocktail shaker or mixing glass. Shake with ice cubes and strain into old-fashioned glass with cracked ice. Twist an orange peel over the surface of the cocktail and drop in the drink to serve.
name: Flannel Shirt
description: Bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler of the Clyde Common in Portland, Oregon, created the Flannel Shirt for an autumnal event. Using classic fall flavors -- apple, earth, spice and smoke -- he whipped up this fleecy, bone-warming drink with the bold backbone of Scotch and a wonderful supporting cast. Morgenthaler says, ''It reminds me of a hot drink that you''d have on Thanksgiving morning -- only served cold.''

preparation: In a mixing glass with ice, combine all ingredients except cider, stir it all up, and strain into glass.  Top with cider.
name: Scottish Orchard
description: Goes well with rich stews, crackling fires, and down vests.

preparation: Build in an old-fashioned glass over ice. Stir until chilled. Garnish with your own best wishes or deepest fears.
name: Diamondback
description: Ostensibly named after the Diamondback Lounge in the Lord Baltimore Hotel.  Has a bit more bite than the titular serpent, but with remarkably less poison.

preparation: Add all of the ingredients, save the flower water, to the mixing glass and stir for several minutes with plenty of cracked and non-cracked ice until well chilled (adding in additional ice as needed along the way). Add/sprinkle the flower water over ice (a large rock cube is preferred by us) that you have placed in the serving glass.  Strain the stirred drink mixture over the ice in the glass, garnish, serve and enjoy!
name: Malena
description: Created and popularized by created by Dushan Zaric of [Employees Only](http://www.employeesonlynyc.com/) in New York.

preparation: Pour all ingredients, except the bitters, into shaker filled with ice. Shake. Pour into large glass, filled with ice. Add Angostura bitters, ''on top''.
name: Planter's Punch
description:
To quote the magazine *Fun*, in 1878:

A wine-glass with lemon juice fill,
Of sugar the same glass fill twice
Then rub them together until
The mixture looks smooth, soft, and nice.

Of rum then three wine glasses add,
And four of cold water please take. A
Drink then you'll have that's not bad—
At least, so they say in Jamaica.

preparation: Build into old fashioned glass filled with ice. Stir gently.
name: Negroni
description: While the drink''s origins are unknown, the most widely reported account is that it was invented in Florence, Italy in 1919, at Cafe Casoni, ex Cafe Giacosa, now called Cafe Cavalli. Count Camillo Negroni invented it by asking the bartender, Fosco Scarselli, to strengthen his favorite cocktail, the Americano, by adding gin rather than the normal soda water. The bartender also added an orange garnish rather than the typical lemon garnish of the Americano to signify that it was a different drink.

preparation: Shake and strain into glass.
name: Vesper
description:
"A dry martini," [Bond] said. "One. In a deep champagne goblet."

"Oui, monsieur."

"Just a moment. Three measures of Gordon's, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it's ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel. Got it?"

"Certainly, monsieur." The barman seemed pleased with the idea.

"Gosh, that's certainly a drink," said Leiter.

Bond laughed. 
"When I'm...er...concentrating," he explained, "I never have more than one drink before dinner. But I do like that one to be large and very strong and very cold and very well-made. I hate small portions of anything, particularly when they taste bad. This drink's my own invention. I'm going to patent it when I can think of a good name."

—Ian Fleming, Casino Royale, Chapter 7, "Rouge et Noir'

name: Clover Club
preparation: Shake with ice cubes. Strain into glass.
description: The Clover Club Cocktail is a drink that pre-dates Prohibition, and is named for the Philadelphia men''s club of the same name, which met in the Bellevue-Stratford hotel.

name: French 75
preparation: Shake with ice cubes, except for champagne. Strain into a champagne flute. Top up with champagne. Stir gently.
description: The drink was created in 1915 at the New York Bar in Paris (Harry's New York Bar) by barman Harry MacElhone. The combination was said to have such a kick that it felt like being shelled with the powerful French 75mm field gun, also called a *75 Cocktail*, or *Soixante Quinze* in French. The French 75 was popularized in America at the Stork Club in New York.

preparation: In a mixing glass with ice, combine all ingredients except cider, stir it all up, and strain into glass.
name: Maple Leaf
description: Try substituting the rye for bourbon for an even sweeter finish.  In terms of maple syrup, you want a Grade B -- something that can contribute flavor as opposed to being overly saccharine.

preparation: Shake well and strain into cocktail glass.
name: Savoy Tango
description: This cocktail is beloved at it's namesake: the [Savoy Hotel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savoy_Hotel) in London, where it was invented.

preparation: Dry shake the egg white and the lime juice. Add the remaining ingredients, ice and shake hard. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
name: Angostura Sour
description: This cocktail was created by Kirk Estopinal and published in the book *Beta Cocktails*, a variation on the Angostura Fizz, which itself was published in Charles Baker's [The Gentlemen's Companion](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614273960?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1614273960&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20) in the 1930s, using half an ounce of bitters and additional rum.

preparation: Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake without ice, add ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass.
name: Astor Hotel Special
description: This delightful drink was originally concoted by the infamous Charles Baker for the Astor House Hotel.  (You may have deduced this from the name.)

preparation: Pour scotch and lime juice into ice-filled collins glass and lightly stir.  Top it off with ginger ale.
name: Mamie Taylor
description: Adapted from Albert Stevens Crockett's 1935 [The Old Wardorf-Astoria Bar Book](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1438244304?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1438244304&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20). The drink first appeared in the *New York Herald* some thirty years prior to Crockett writing his book. The namesake of the drink -- a certain Mrs. Taylor -- is still unknown.

preparation: Stir in mixing glass with ice cubes. Strain into chilled glass.
name: Manhattan
description: One of the most popular and classic cocktails; one of the six basic cocktails in [The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1603111646?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1603111646&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20) by David A. Embury.  Try tinkering with the amount of vermouth or substituting the base liquor for something else in the whiskey family.

name: Blood and Sand
preparation: Shake and strain into glass.
description: Named after the 1922 movie of the same name.  First appeared in 1930, in the [Savoy Cocktail Book](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1862057729?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1862057729&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20).

preparation: Shake and strain over rocks (use a fine strainer if you want a lot of froth).
name: Jungle Bird
description: The Jungle Bird is a relatively recent Tiki concoction, credited to the Aviary Bar at the Kuala Lumpur Hilton hotel in 1978. It was first published in John J. Poister's [New American Bartender's Guide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0451205243?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=0451205243&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20) in 1989, but languished in obscurity until it was unearthed and published in Jeff 'Beachbum' Berry's [Intoxica](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0943151570?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=0943151570&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20) in 2002. Since then, it has become very popular, particularly among the bitter-loving cocktail crowd, with notable bartenders putting their own personal stamp on it.

name: Alaska
preparation: Stir and strain into a chilled glass.
description: Oddly enough, there is very little known about the origins of the Alaska cocktail. The most that people seem to be able to ascertain is that this has nothing to do with Alaska or Eskimos, as seen from the description in [The Savoy Cocktail Book](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1862057729?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1862057729&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20), and instead is attributed to originating in South Carolina.

preparation: Mix and serve.
name: Gimlet
description: *Why on earth this stroke of genius stands unheralded and unsung in this fair and allegedly free land of ours shall, to us, always be a mystery like who it is that designs expensive radio cabinets, why all cinema stars long to ruin themselves playing highbrow roles, and why good prize fighters want to write fiction. Throughout the whole swing of the Far East, starting with Bombay-down the Malabar Coast to Colombo; to Penang, Singapore, Hong Kong and Shanghai, the Gimlet is just as well known as our Martini here.* ~ Charles H. Baker, [The Gentlemen''s Companion](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614273960?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1614273960&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20)

preparation: Make a large lemon twist, rub it on the glass rim, drop it into the glass. Stir first two ingredients with ice. Strain into a glass. Top with beer and and then sparkling wine.
name: Field & Cellar
description: This is a *shandy* -- a beer cocktail -- created by the fine folks at [Boozenerds](http://boozenerds.com/2014/10/26/shandies/).  Generally, shandies are considered warm-weather drinks.

name: Samsara
preparation: Stir first 3 ingredients with ice. Strain into a glass. Top with beer.
description: This is a *shandy* -- a beer cocktail -- created by the fine folks at [Boozenerds](http://boozenerds.com/2014/10/26/shandies/).  Generally, shandies are considered warm-weather drinks.

preparation: Shake first 3 ingredients with ice. Strain into a glass. Top with beer. Garnish with a lime wheel.
name: Draughtsman
description: This is a *shandy* -- a beer cocktail -- created by the fine folks at [Boozenerds](http://boozenerds.com/2014/10/26/shandies/).  Generally, shandies are considered warm-weather drinks.

preparation: Stir long and well with ice in a mixing glass and strain into a cocktail glass.
name: Boulevardier
description: From Harry McElhone''s 1927 [Barflies and Cocktails](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1603111697?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creativeASIN=1603111697&linkCode=xm2&tag=barback-20), this drink is a darker cousin of the Negroni -- having subtituted bourbon for gin.
